acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Not classified from 48 hours EC50=345000microg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (AQUIRE, 2003).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 2,500mg/kg (RTECS (2006)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category R by NTP (2005) and Group 2A by IARC (1990).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since it was not water-insolubility (the water-solubility =2500mg/L (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), and acute toxicity was low, it was classified into Not classified.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data on the kick-off temperature and decomposition energy (though the substance contains nitro groups with its oxygen budget calculated at -114).

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests), positive data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests) and somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests), and the absence of data on germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, described in IARC 50 (1990) and IARC 10 (1976).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being organic compounds containing oxygen bound to the elements other than carbon and hydrogen

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of pup malformation including hydrocephalus and cleft palate observed in rat teratogenicity studies, described in IARC 10 (1976) (though no data are available regarding parental toxicity).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though containing nitro groups with explosive properties.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (bone marrow, nervous system, digestive system),
Category 2 (heart)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (bone marrow, nervous system, digestive system)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (heart)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "a case report of a 5-yr-old child who developed aplastic anemia and died of acute myeloblastic leukemia 1 year after chloramphenicol was therapeutically administered," "a case of a 63-yr-old man who developed bone marrow suppression 4 months after chloramphenicol was administered at a dose of 12g" (IARC 10 (1976)), "other adverse effects of prolonged administration included skin eruption, gastrointestinal disorder and nervous system damage" (IARC 50 (1990)), "there is symmetrical loss of ganglion cells from retina and atrophy of fibers in optic nerve," "cardiovascular collapse with cardiomyopathic changes and impaired left ventricular function was documented by echocardiography" (HSDB (2005)). Since the priority rating of the referenced study reporting the effects on the heart in humans is 2, these effects are classified into Category 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
